free_txt: General Electric Test Reactor,
Vallecitos, California.
BP
General Electric Test Reactor,
Vallecitos, California.
The energy spectrum consists principally of thermal
neutrons in this well-moderated reactor.
The 155Fm target material was separated from its
parent the beta emitter 255Es, which was present in
an einsteinium fraction of the following composition:
1.0 microg 253Es, 3.4x10**-5 microg 255Es. The
fermium was separated from the einsteinium by elution
from a column Dowex-50 resin with 0.4 M ammonium
alpha-hydroxyisobutyrate solution, pH = 3.85 at 85
degrees C. The target composition at the start of the
irradiation was 1.43x10**9 atoms 2SSFm and
1.21x10**10 atoms 253Es. The 253Es was present in the
target as a contaminant because of incomplete
chemical purification of the fermium.
157 +- 2 min. measured by authors.
No details on sources of uncertainties.
The total neutron exposure was 6 h at an
average flux of 8.6x10**13 n/cm2 sec, which was
determined by the activation of a cobalt wire. The
flux measurement is estimated to be accurate to +-
10%. After removal from the reactor, the target was
dissolved in 80% HCI - 20% ethanol solution and
treated to remove fission products. This solution was
saturated with HCl gas and loaded directly onto a
Dowex-50x12 (colloidal form) ion-exchange column.
Elution of the column with HCl-ethanol solution
resulted in the purification of the combined
einsteinium and fermium fraction from most fission
products, particularly the rare earths. The decay of
spontaneous fissions in the sample was measured by
counting in an ionization chamber with the amplifier
biased to record fission events only. In order to
calculate the neutron capture cross section of 255Fm,
the following cross section estimates were assumed
sigma(n,fission) = 200 b; for 256Fm,
sigma(n,destruction) = 20 b. However, the calculation
is insensitive to the values assumed since
neutron-induced reactions account for only 2% of the
destruction of 25SFm during the irradiation; the
remainder is due to alpha decay. In the case of 256Fm,
neutron-induced reactions account for < 10**-4 of the
destruction rate as compared to the 157 min decay.
page 232.
Cross section estimate: The general trend for neutron
capture cross sections is to decrease with an
increase in mass number for isotopes of a given
element on the neutron excess side of stability. An
odd-even effect is also seen, e.g. the odd-mass
fermium isotopes have capture cross sections somewhat
higher than neighboring even-mass isotopes. Thus, we
may conclude that the capture cross section of 257Fm
for a well-thermalized reactor spectrum is less than
page 232.
